> I am starting to think you just label anything you don't like as tyranny, any decision you personally dislike is tyrannical.

Do you think Kim Jong Un thinks of himself as a tyrant? He probably says the same thing when people question him. Don't look at the most brutal people in history and set that as the standard for being tyrannical. It's possible to be *less* tyrannical and still be tyrannical.

That's a completely different situation. If I run your car into a train, it destroys your car. But servers are merely using a *copy* of the software and nothing they do can wreck it for anyone but them. That's like saying if I clone your car I shouldn't be allowed to wreck my own duplicate.

> Maybe don't sell accounts?

You're using circular logic here. When I say "Mojang can't ban the account any more than the server" you come back to this, which explains nothing btw. "If you don't think we should completely *BAN AND DESTROY* something, it means you support it! There's no such thing as agreeing to disagree, and there's no middle ground. You either support something or support eradicating it!"

> There shouldn't be rules for how you're allowed to use something you bought in the first place.

It seems to me you don't dislike tyranny, you dislike the existence of rules period. You think there should be zero rules anywhere for anything and that people should be able to do whatever they want, and I hate to tell ya but even in an ancap society there's going to be rules. You have the NAP for one but communities may agree upon a set of rules.

>  I could sell you a drink on the condition that you can't give it to anyone else, but it would be extremely petty and dictorial and few people would agree to that. Why is this any different? Plus, it's unMinecraft-like: all the initial terms and conditions for MC were written solely to protect Mojang from legal issues. 

So basically if I buy a Honda, I should be allowed to strap it up with C4 and drive it right into Honda corp HQ and detonate the C4?

> They clearly had no actual interest in them until recent years when Jeb suddenly decided to start enforcing it for no reason.

No, he enforced it because of legitimate community outcry, not the outcry of a select few privileged community members since I know you will bring up Reddit again.

> In fact, Notch actually had plans to completely open-source Minecraft in the future (I assume this was botched by MS though) and it practically is even because of MCP.

Yeah, well guess who made the decision to sell Minecraft to Microsoft in the first place, who took the offer. It wasn't Jeb so that narrows it down a bit.

> That's literally like saying, "you say you don't like tyranny, but aren't you guilty of the same thing by telling Democrats and Republicans they can't use big government to control people?"

Do you even know what tyranny is? Because you seem to conflate the existence of rules as tyranny when in reality tyranny is defined as "cruel and oppressive government or rule" and I would not consider telling cancer to stop being cancer as cruel, and last time I checked Mojang isn't a government they're a private entity. If Mojang wanted to be tyrannical they'd force server owners to pay a license fee to host Minecraft servers (when in fact you don't even need to own the game to run a server, you can straight up download the server jar for free) or go after 2B2T.

> No, they shouldn't be banning people at all, nor should they be shutting down servers they don't like.

Wait wait wait hold on here, so you're saying that a private server operator should be disallowed from banning someone from his own server? Ok so they can host P2W, but not ban users who disrupt the server?

> If you want to do something in a world, does Mojang have to do it for you?

If it's an issue involving Minecraft, ummmm yes they do since it's their product.

> Of course not, and likewise they shouldn't have to manage your server for you either. As for accounts, you're likening it to an account on a website when in reality it's little more than a way to purchase the game.

They're not managing servers, they're enforcing the license agreement that these server operators agreed to. Also, it's actually a bit more than "just a way to purchase the game" it's actually an integral part of Minecraft multiplayer and pretty much always has been. Even before Microsoft bought Minecraft if you were not authenticated to your Mojang account you were not going to be connecting to any servers unless they disabled the authentication which some such as the Meloncraft example someone else brought up. 

> Didn't know we were talking about alts, which I don't recall not being allowed, but anyway this is a problem that's practically impossible to solve.

Stop being dishonest, we're talking about the sale of accounts which is primarily used to enable alt accounting. Hell there's even 3rd party launchers that connect to a service where you can swap alts on the fly specifically for server ban-evasion.

> Mojang can do little more than the server.

Well other than ban the account, which again is their right as per the agreement you made with them when you purchased their software.

> As you can see on any website, the only solution is IP or machine address banning, things that are so easily manipulated that even intelligence agencies can't trace them, and IP bans are already available to servers. Evaders will always get around anything. This is one reason I don't think "ban evasion" in itself should be an offense at all, the other being that it's super petty
